85% in a couple of months, if not mistaken, and within a year 100%. The solution seemed similar, an injection with a mix of stem cells, some other proteins, some other agents, and the body would by itself regenerate, creating that new «connections» and the brain would just be needed to rewire all the new information from the new stimulus with the place where now the brain was understanding them. Like for example, before if you would touch a leg and the brain would recognize it it a back side, now, with the new wiring it would understand it with the front opposite side (just an example), but, even though recognizing it with new places in the brain, it would perform the same stuff, after therapy, like to relearn to walk again, but with a fully function machine, or connection, in the spinal cord.

Which show was that? Anyone else watched it? I believe they also mentioned the technology to grow a human ear in mice, same technology, different end result, with the mix in the injection pointing to grow cartilage instead of neurons...

Seriously? Intentionally severing healthy rats' spinal cords? That's truly disgusting! Do you know so little of rats that you are you unaware that many male elderly rats are naturally susceptible to hind leg paralysis? Why not use these rats for your studies? That would be both humane & practical, but this is just gross. Everyone is so excited at this "amazing" discovery but no one is the least bit disturbed about the animal, whose spine has been severed, is strapped in a harness, has an electrode stimulant directly attached to its brain, & is forced to (albeit involuntarily) walk, run & stand in an upright position on a treadmill. If this was forced upon a human people would be in an uproar. It's also not all made "okay" just because the rat receives chocolate, which is also bad for them. Rats are not bipedal. They can momentarily stand on their hind legs, but forcing them to walk on them is very unnatural for them. I chose to watch this because I thought it was rehabilitating disabled rats, I didn't realize it was subjecting them to abuse.

I'm bothered with a question:
Why are they able to test this with a (paralyzed) Rat, but not actualized with a (paralyzed) human (yet) ? It not like inducing motivation has to happen in a lab. If they can support the weight of a paralyzed person, they could start right away.
But I imagine that it would be difficult to motivate so strongly a person, and that is why we cannot yet consistently test this.
(*Added later. But then again, there are cases where doctors thought recovery, the ability to walk, or to talk, impossible based off physical data and observance, and yet a person makes a recovery though sheer will and effort. Motivated drive and making a decision (to not give up).)
Its easier to motivate a rat (with chocolate though instincts) but how to motivate so strongly a human?
But because they can synthesize hormones, smells, tastes, brain chemicals, its not like they can't simulate something desirable. Perhaps that "chocolate" may not physically exist, only a mere representation of it, but they can make the person believe that it is real through smells, tastes, or chemicals that induce something desirable, or something worth motivating oneself for. Perhaps, 4D virtual reality, or AR will have a place for this. To simulate (however artificially) something desirable.
A Rat's motivation or decision to want to walk is due to instinctual drives (no choice but to follow instinct).
Whereas Humans have instinctual drives too, but "chocolate" wouldn't necessary cut it. Because humans have instincts but by choice, humans have the ability to not follow instincts. Where perhaps the difficulty and complexity arises. The motivating factor, unless not induced by chemicals to stimulate specific areas of the brain as desirable and feel-good, what motivates a person will differ in form. However the chemicals involved will be the same in varying degrees.
If then, the problem really becomes.... Not everyone has what motivates them to the extent of complete exertion of ones being so much so as to decide to move ones legs even if physically, we think that we can't move them. In other words, choosing and deciding supra-rationally. Making a decision against what we see or think.

For a Rat, "chocolate" is the best thing that it has ever tasted or most likely can taste in its life.
Chocolate contains phenylethylamine which can raise levels of endorphins, the pleasure-giving substances, in the brain. Therefore, this may be what is causing a Rat to desire chocolate. Stimulating the strong motivation.
Chocolate may not necessarily work for a human, but possibly if it were these phenylethylamines or something for that person, subjectively or objectively raises endorphins in the brain for a human being that could be the object that a human can strongly aspire to reach.
Though I think that the same parts of the brain no matter who, would be stimulated in varying degrees, (this being an objective response, and how the human is created ) but the form that stimulates those responses in the brain will be relative to each individual person.

The natural way for a human would be for that person to find what he is wiling to supera-rationally exert himself for. Or even the search itself can be the supra-rational motivating factor.
An artificial way to going about this, would be by inducing via the things that cause those responses in the brain through simulation. However, unless that person themselves supra-rationally decides to, no amount of brain inducing chemicals, or stimulating specific regions in the brain would be able to influence their decision.

But, as this Rat needs an outside influence, or be stimulated, help to motivate what is within [making ones own decision, either to walk or not walk] , so can we hugely benefit, better yet the world would be such a better place if we as humans were to encourage and help motivate one another, exactly (albeit for a human) as this person is exerting effort in trying any thing they possibly can to motivate that Rat to move forward.
We desperately need to.

I find it annoying how hypocritical people in the comments can be, they claim that ''those rats'' (notice how they put 'those', only one was used in the video, nice exaggeration) "suffered uneccesary pain in order to benefit another species". Actually, when watching the video, I heard them mention 'rehabilitation', which if you didn't know the meaning of, is when someone takes care of an injured animal or abandoned animal baby and sends them back to the wild or someplace else that can care for them well. So no, not only are we also benefiting ourselves if we continue to do this, we are also helping other animals, why whine over one rat getting hurt when this test could potentially help humans AND animals? If the rat was in bad condition and was treated horribly, then yes I'd find it unfair for the rodent, but it seemed to be clean and well treated, heck it got a bloody éclair. I think it is nice that we do this, even if it puts one small rat in pain, it at least goes to help paralysed animals and humans, both young and old.

Though I dont like animal research ( I own pet rats ) i realize that they are needed ( like many other types of animals like monkeys unfortunately ) in order to advance science/medicine so that we as humans can benefit. I dont like that most are destroyed after an experiment. I think they should be cared for after going through this ( & a ratslife is usually a couple months longer than 2yrs ) out of respect for them as life forms ( admittedly there are circumstances that it'd be better to euthenize them depending on whats been done ) but I'm not gonna go try to shut down labs that might discover something that really benefits humanity. I do think as a whole that the animals should be treated better & there are ways that can be done inexpensively.  & should be implemented. Yes it bothered me watching this knowing that poor rat was purposely paralyzed,but if humans really ( No open ended funding for no progress experiments or ones that are questionalble or that do the same experiment when the result is a known thing ) benefit & labs improve the subjects treatment then I cant complain. The rats I got were sold as FEEDERS, so they've been rescued from becoming reptile food & I treat them like royalty & show them limitess effection,even to the 1 who just refuses to try to stop biting me,as I realize she had to live in a tiny fish tank @ the store & watched 2 litters of babies all get taken away, then she got sold to me pregnant & I had to give away a bunch, I had 7 of them though, they do die of old age but I take care of her regardless that she's had to learn humans are shitty( thank god all her kids I raised are affectionate as all hell ) & labs should do the same for test animals. I admit that when its no longer neccessary to use these beings in tests Ill be happy. So unless youre saving same creature from the fate of being food or a test subject & really takig care of it yourself, stop demandingthe labs stop ( they wont ) & start demanding better treatment for the animals that do have to be tested on. TO everyone defending animal experiments for the supposed sake of advancing medicine/ developing "groundbreaking" therapies: Do you know how long people have been doing this for?! How often have scientists proclaimed they were sooooo close to finding a cure for cancer or neurological disease? To give just one example, years ago I was listening to a science podcast and they were talking about the "unbelievable" progress made by scientists who supposedly had found a way to treat a kind of brain tumor (could have been Glioblastoma, I am not sure) by injecting who knows what stuff into mice. MICE. They talked about how this could POTENTIALLY be a HUGE STEP forward in the treatment of humans, and so on, only to conclude the segment by saying that it is uncertain if this method will ever make it into medical TRIAL. And you know what? I never heard anything about this great cancer breakthrough again, and I doubt that we will. As far as I know, the go-to treatments are still chemo and radiation therapy, since like forever...
There are so many resources wasted on animal research because a lot of scientists are just interested in getting their papers published, and not much else. Seriously. You have a lot of huge egos in many academic fields. Especially in medicine. Smart people but not necessarily innovative thinkers. There may be many idealistic people who genuinely want to contribute to scientific progress - but there are even more who are just narcissists who need their academic title and who want to get published.

If you are genuinely interested in learning more (and not just defending your human supremacist position^^), get an alternative perspective on animal testing by having a look at what more ethically-minded doctors have to say about it (PCRM website, or google alternatives to animal testing or sth like that).

Yes, i also feel bad for the painful experiments they do on rats, but its not abuse, when somebody does something, you shouldnt focus on what they do, but the result and outcome or what they are trying to acomplish, for example, if these scientists were to harm these rats for no reasonable or beneficial reason, just for their own delight and fun, then that would be very cruel and abusive, but scientists are doing this for a good reason. Remeber, it is sad that they do this to rats, but it is not for fun, it is for the good of all humanity, curing paralysis, cancer, understanding animals, learning about our own mind and body, etc, and if we can help ourselves survive, then that in return will help us, help rats, and every animal on earth. I LOVE animals, and hate animal abuse, but lets all be honest, the existence and survival of the entire human race is more important than the suffering of a few rats. The outcome and result is what matters, lets not be shallow and react instantly to what others do , we must take the time to think about the result of what happens, think about if it will be beneficial or reasonable. Some may think that these are just simple tests on animals, but these experiments are essential and beneficial for the future of every living organism on earth.

Though I agree that this is borderline animal cruelty, it is true that the research done in this experiment, and a huge amount of other experiments involving for example animals, could be considered necessary, and the downsides of the research (animal cruelty in many cases) don't outweigh the positive effects of conducting the experiment. For example, just to make a point, it would, although morally difficult, be worth it to conduct research involving animal cruelty in order to make medical advances that could potentially save thousands of human lives.

You could of course argue that humans could consent to taking part in experiments with medical purposes, but in some cases nobody would consent, but the result (saving thousands of people) would still be worth the animal cruelty in question. On a side note, humans have since the dawn of intelligence and technology been, to some degree involuntary, testing out medicine (in the form of plants, animal extracts, etc.) to find out what works and what doesn't, often resulting in the ones not working (and the ones working, but with side effects) causing pain, death and other negative effects that instead animals are subject to today.

As a thought experiment; you are in a room with a rat and not much else, and in a cage next to the room, there are 1000 people that are going to die unless you perform various experiments on the rat, some of them causing large amounts of pain. I believe that most people would do as instructed in order to save the humans in the cage.

Then, imagine the experiment, but with a restrained human in addition to the rat, and with the same instructions except that you could choose whether to perform the tasks on the rat or on the human. This would be a lot more complicated, since the human for example could consent to the cruelty you were forced to subject to either of the subjects, but I still think that the rat would be the option many people would go for in either case, with or without the human consenting to the cruelty.

This is a very simple comparison to how animal testing works. It's bad and it's cruel, but it's still necessary and worth it.

Also, just so people remember; animals in nature don't have very good lives. They are subject to starvation, fear, sickness, injuries, and a lot of other horrible experiences, and virtually no wild animlas die from natural causes, especially not after living happy lives. There is also the question of how aware they actually are of pain etc., as we don't know much about the conciousness of animals. Perhaps they don't experience pain the same way we do, since their primary reason for not wanting to experience pain (which potentially leads to them dying) is the fear of not being able to further their own genetic material. If their conciousness allowed them to decide, I think that being subjected to cruelty similar to the one they would find in nature anyway, but while having access to food and water, could be a tempting option for many animals, even though it seems horrible when you first think about it.

Please take a minute to consider which things deserve rights and which things don't when you consider an ethics system.

It is evident that all species don't deserve the same consideration (aka, mosquito to human, rat to bacteria, etc, and there are also grey areas with robots), so where do we draw the line? Do we trust our empathy? Our empathy says "Care more about brain dead family member than about chimpanzee" or "Care less about gay people" if we're homophobic, so let's not use it more than strictly necessary.

For example, it is pretty clear that most advanced animals, like people, cows, or even rats, ARE able to suffer, and so we should limit their suffering if we do experiments on them. It is also quite clear that the level of consciousness of a rat is nowhere near that of a human. So in my ethics, torture of an animal is wrong, but killing it without making it hurt isn't that bad, because in my ethics you need consciousness to have a right to life.

When you decide to be a vegan or a vegetarian or be against animal experimentation, don't do it just out of empathy. Think about your ethics system and how your life choices fit in within it.

i just wanna quickly say something about people debating whether or not the nature of this experiment is ethical. i cant speak for others, but when i say i dont support animal testing, i dont mean for medicinal use in any way. i mean for the use of makeup and lotions and things that are not necessary to our survival and scientific knowledge. these kind of tests and other like them are incredibly important to our progression in the science of our own bodies and disabilities.
i dont understand why people are bringing vegetarianism/veganism into this because theyre pretty unrelated and two completely difference stances on ethicality. you dont need to eat meat to live (this is a genuine unbiased fact) but we do need tests like these to survive. we wouldnt have the knowledge we do on a lot of things if it werent for tests on animals, which sucks, but at the point were at, we dont have much of a choice.
in addition, anyone who claims they dont need modern medicine or that they dont need these tests, is incredibly privileged to not have any chronic health conditions or disabilities that require the use of medicine to live or at the very least, not spend every moment in agonizing pain.

I'm not convinced that there was a meaningful interaction between the brain and legs. The rat's legs responded to the treadmill moving underneath it, in the same sense, I think the rat "decided" to move by what looked clearly to be the manipulation (the tilting) of the harness setup, which simulated the treadmill moving underneath it, to get that involuntary reaction to get what it wants.

Years ago, I suffered a spinal cord injury.  I was crushed under 3000 pounds of stone and among my injuries were 18 bone fractures including my L-2 vertebra.  The spinal cord injury was incomplete, meaning it was not severed completely, but crushed.  I was initially paralyzed from the waist down, but through reconstructive surgery and LOTS of physical therapy, I am now able to walk again.  I still suffer many residual effects from the spinal cord injury which will only be corrected through some new technology.  This video is GREAT news for people like me.  

I have also learned that despite the fact that spinal cord neurons do not regenerate by themselves (that cannot be regrown directionally), scientists have been able to make spinal cord neurons grow across a "bridge" made from a silicon chip.  This news, along with the testing being done in this video, gives great hope to people like me. Thank you for posting this video!  I sincerely hope that folks like these keep up the good work!!!

To all those animal cruelty activists down in the comment section  this may come off as a little rude and for that I apologize but I must ask, how come when setting out rat poison or rat glue or mouse traps is normally called pest control but when paralyzing a rat and making it walk again is called animal cruelty. Now I am in no way suggesting that I am for animal cruelty I can't even stand it when passerby's throw rocks at my dogs but I'm sure that all of us have opened our pantry once in a while to find half of the cheese or biscuits or noodles or oreos or even important documents completely destroyed by rats. Now I ask you do you allow these rats to continue destroying your food, or do you implement pest control, please remember that whether you do it yourself or you hire someone the chances of that rat getting away with its life intact is slim to none. I know how hard it is to catch a rat to set it free somewhere else so I would like to ask you guys to stop being such hypocrites, this rat has had a far better life than those rats living on  your scraps and bits of paper and it is helping treat paralysis not only in humans but in every vertebrae on earth. That's all I had to say, I know that it might not be received well but rats are pests and I bet more of them are being exterminated right now than helping make revolutionary scientific discoveries.

There are institutions (IACUC and IRB) that govern research on animals (yes, humans are animals), including specific protections for special populations (e.g., children; prisoners). There have been cases of unethical research (e.g., Tuskegee experiments; Harry Harlow's later work) but these are rare and make up a very small percentage of studies. We owe a great deal of our scientific knowledge and progress to research. Are we really willing to sacrifice that to ease the conscious of a minority?

Lack of calcium, animal protein, milk acidifies the body pH which in turn triggers a biological correction. Calcium is an excellent acid neutralizer and the biggest storage of calcium in the body is – you guessed it… in the bones. I never said that animal testing is totally okay - it's just a necessary evil. Computational models are unreliable. Experimentation on cells in a petri dish alone is insufficient - an animal is a sum of many different cells working in conjunction so testing on cells isolated from a body is just not enough. Testing on unicellular eukaryotes is insufficient - they are too distantly removed from humans for the data to be anything but probabitve.

And I value sentience - human beings can think and are self aware, unlike most animals, and so testing on them is cruel because the subject and tester are aware of both. I don't like testing on dolphins or primates (I thoroughly dislike primate testing) because I think that these animals are self aware and possess some level of sentience that makes testing on them exceptionally cruel.

Second, what kind of alternatives are you talking about? Computational models? Theories tested out on a computational model will ALWAYS have to be validated via testing on subjects - whether they be human or rats. How can you say that "this drug works fine on the computational experiments" and expect people to use it?

Cont. What rights do animals deserve? The old "does an animal get the right to vote?" question is answered easy "no". Why? It is not because we have dismissed animals outright without equality, it is because we assess them, and come to the conclusion they can not cognitively understand the importance, nor do they have the ability to express, said right. So we move to torture, and ask, is it morally right to hurt a moral agent for the possibility of saving/helping another? Do numbers matter? etc.

In other words, one may have a right that another does not given circumstances, biology, understanding, etc. Take for example a human case first(move to animals next), women have a right to have an abortion, and men do not. This is not because of inequality, correct? It is just simple physiology in this case, women have an ability to bare children, men do not. If men could have children, we would base the same standards on them as we do women now.

All science is equally valuable. Physics increases our understanding of how everything in existence works. Chemistry helps us develop new materials for use in equipment both in the consumer and research markets, as well as develop medicine. Biology finds the cause of ailments and what needs to be done to fix them so the chemists know what they are aiming for. Ecology helps us determine impacts on everything in a given area should something happen to one member or group. Science is a collective.

It is reliable when it has to do with the most basic biochemical reactions within a close relative. The rat is a vertebrate mammal. Their neurons work like any other vertebrate. Chemical signals create electrical impulses that release other chemicals which are understood as information to direct bodily functions. 
Testing on already injured vertebrates is the way to go. It opens up to human studies, it has the potential to help already injured animals and there is no harm intentionally inflicted

I doubt they just got the idea for this randomly and began animal testing for no good reason. The science behind this has been around for a while. Scientists have been able to regenerate nerves in the lab before. These scientists had a hypothesis which existing scientific knowledge indicated would be correct and so they tested it. It is unethical to induce the injuries, yes, but scientists do this sort of thing for the benefit of all humanity (and other animals too). That is hardly psychopathic.
Now, is the rat able to feel? or perceive touch in its lower limbs? or is it simply a reflex causing the walking motion?

Perhaps. The difficulty is in balancing the ethics of not doing such research and the harm that causes to people, versus the harm done to the animals in conducting this research. The reality is that for now we (generalising obviously) value our own species above others (in a similar way to which we (typically) value ourselves, family, and friends over strangers). Whatever you decide, you are making an ethical decision, which inevitably hurts someone/thing. Each decision can be challenged.

Most researchers know that they tread on the boundaries of ethics, and that they must tread carefully, else face harsh consequences.
